we are talking about different use cases. ill try to clarify :

1 - legal requirements : in some countries you have to store information
about who connects to your service, when you are a service provider.
basically the reason is that logging ip helps the police finds hostile
people, for example when you are victim of ddos.

this is the webserver job. period. nothing to implement in owncloud.

2 - anti-brute force measure

two cases :

2-a you use a reverse proxy for authentication. for example, apache does
the authentication (using ldap, openid, whatever you like), then gives the
uid to owncloud via authorization headers. this is the best case. apache
logs info itself about failed auth (basically in serious environments we
try to have all security stuff in the rp, not in the application : auth,
log, anti ddos, https, etc)

2-b you use native owncloud authentication (via form). then apache doesnt
know when an authentication failed. it just sees perfect 200 http requests.
so we need information about failed auth in owncloud log.

regards,
stephane

@raydiation :-1: on captchas.
1. they are 3rd party, supplied by google.
2. thus you'd need an api key.
3. captchas are pretty hard to read sometimes, resulting in bad ux.

thinking about it an admin should have the choice between owncloud's brute-force-prevention and just bad-login report, to use something else instead, defaulting to owncloud's protection.

* there are other captcha libs than recaptcha which dont need internet access
* will only show after 3 failed attempts in under 30 minutes or something like that

apart from that no one should have to set up fail2ban. it should be secure by default. otherwise we're basically requiring everyone to setup fail2ban also.

>otherwise we're basically requiring everyone to setup fail2ban also.

well, bruteforce-protection #1603 will supply something owncloud for that.
this may be disabled, but still logging bad logins, so fail2ban could do its job.
yeah going with both should be better.
